unnormalised: Manufacturers in India are increasingly focusing on robust quality control measures to meet rising consumer expectations and global standards. A recent FICCI report highlighted a 20% increase in investment towards quality assurance programs within the automotive and electronics sectors in the last fiscal year.

unnormalised: This surge is driven by initiatives like the "Make in India" campaign and a growing awareness of the costs associated with defective products – reputational damage and potential recall expenses, sometimes running into Rs. 50 Crore for a single product line.

unnormalised: Dr. Anjali Sharma, a professor at IIT-Madras, emphasizes that statistical process control (SPC) and Six Sigma methodologies are being widely adopted. "Even traditional industries, like those manufacturing ingredients for Onam Sadhya, are implementing stricter quality checks to ensure food safety and consistent taste," she notes.

unnormalised: Companies are also exploring AI-powered quality control systems that use machine vision to detect defects with far greater accuracy than manual inspection. This helps in minimizing wastage and improves efficiency, especially vital when producing large batches of popular dishes like biryani for festive seasons. The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) is expected to release revised guidelines on quality management by Q4 2024, further strengthening the ecosystem.
